Vector Spaces and Rings

New Definitions

Definitions already covered in Prelims Linear Algebra are omitted.

  • A field is a set F\mathbb FF equipped with two binary operations +++ and ×\times× where:
    • (F,+,0)(\mathbb F,+,0)(F,+,0) and (F∖{0},×,1)(\mathbb F\setminus \{0\},\times,1)(F∖{0},×,1) form two Abelian groups;
    • ×\times× distributes over +++.
  • The characteristic of a field is min⁡{p:1+⋯+1undefinedp times=0}\min \{p:\underbrace{1+\cdots+1}_{p\text{ times}}=0\}min{p:p times1+⋯+1​​=0}, if such a ppp exists, and 000 otherwise.
    • In Zp, p\mathbb{Z}_p,\,pZp​,p prime, the characteristic is ppp.
    • In Q\mathbb QQ, the characteristic is 000.
  • Hom(V,W)\text{Hom}(V,W)Hom(V,W) is the vector space of linear maps from VVV to WWW.
  • A linear map ϕ∈Hom(V,W)\phi \in\mathrm{Hom}(V,W)ϕ∈Hom(V,W) is an (vector space) isomorphism if it is bijective.

Rings

  • A ring is a set RRR equipped with two binary operations +++ and ×\times×, where (R,+,0)(R,+,0)(R,+,0) is an Abelian group, and ×\times× is associative and distributive.
    • Commutativity, identity, and inverses are not required for multiplication.
  • A subring is a subset of a ring that is also a ring.
  • In a ring RRR, an ideal I⊲RI \lhd RI⊲R is a non-empty subset that is closed and absorbing: closed:  ∀s,t∈I,s−t∈Iabsorbing:  ∀r∈R,rI,Ir⊆I\begin{align*}\text{closed: }\, & \forall s,t\in I,&&s-t\in I\\ \text{absorbing: }\, & \forall r\in R, &&rI,Ir \subseteq I\end{align*}closed: absorbing: ​∀s,t∈I,∀r∈R,​​s−t∈IrI,Ir⊆I​
    • For example, 2Z⊲Z2\mathbb{Z}\lhd\mathbb{Z}2Z⊲Z is an ideal.
    • Absorbing means that “nothing goes out of III via multiplication.”
    • Ideals are to rings what normal subgroups are to groups.
  • Ideals are always subrings with the definition of rings we use in this course (i.e. not requiring a multiplicative identity).

Ring Homomorphisms

  • A ring homomorphism is a map between rings that commutes with the ring operations.
  • First Isomorphism Theorem: for any ring homomorphism ϕ:R→S\phi: R\to Sϕ:R→S, ker⁡ϕ⊲R, Im ϕ is a subring of S,R/ker⁡ϕ≅Im ϕ.\begin{align*}&\ker\phi\lhd R,\\&\,\text{Im}\,\phi\text{ is a subring of}\ S,\\& R/\ker \phi\cong \text{Im}\, \phi.\end{align*}​kerϕ⊲R,Imϕ is a subring of S,R/kerϕ≅Imϕ.​

Proof: the first two statements can be directly verified from definitions.
The isomorphism is given by r+ker⁡ϕ→ϕ(r)r+\ker\phi\to\phi(r)r+kerϕ→ϕ(r); verifiy that it is indeed a homomorphism and a bijection.

The Polynomial RIng

  • Given a field F\mathbb FF, F[x]\mathbb F[x]F[x] denotes the ring of polynomials over it, i.e.the set of polynomials with coefficients taken from F\mathbb FF.
    • note that xxx is just a place holder, and we might as well represent polynomials with a list of their coefficients

Division Algorithm and its Corollaries

  • The division algorithm states that given polynomials a(x),b(x)∈F[x]a(x), b(x)\in \mathbb F[x]a(x),b(x)∈F[x], there exists a quotient and a remainder, q(x),r(x)∈F[x]q(x),r(x)\in \mathbb F[x]q(x),r(x)∈F[x] such that: f=qg+r,  deg⁡r<deg⁡ff=qg+r,\ \ \deg r<\deg ff=qg+r,  degr<degf

Proof: induct on the degree of fff; reduce the power in h≡f−q1gh\equiv f-q_{1}gh≡f−q1​g with a suitable q1q_1q1​ that cancels out the highest power.
Then the induction hypothesis gives h=q2g+r~h=q_{2}g+\tilde rh=q2​g+r~, and substituting for hhh gives the result.

  • If f∈F[x],a∈F,f\in \mathbb{F}[x],a\in \mathbb{F},f∈F[x],a∈F, then [f(a)=0]⇒[(x−a)∣f]\Big[f(a)=0\Big]\Rightarrow \Big[(x-a)|f\Big][f(a)=0]⇒[(x−a)∣f].

Proof: apply the division algorithm to get q,r:f=(x−a)q+rq,r:f=(x-a)q+rq,r:f=(x−a)q+r.
The remainder rrr, which has degree 000 hence constant, is r=[(x−a)q(x)+r]x=a=f(a)=0r=[(x-a)q(x)+r]_{x=a}=f(a)=0r=[(x−a)q(x)+r]x=a​=f(a)=0.

  • Bezout’s Lemma for polynomials: given non-zero a,b∈F[x]a,b\in \mathbb{F}[x]a,b∈F[x], and c=gcd⁡(a,b),c=\gcd(a,b),c=gcd(a,b), ∃s,t∈F[x]: as+bt=c\exists s,t\in \mathbb{F}[x]:\ as+bt=c∃s,t∈F[x]: as+bt=c

Proof: by dividing the equation by c, we only need to find s,t:as+bt=1s,t:as+bt=1s,t:as+bt=1 when gcd⁡(a,b)=1\gcd(a,b)=1gcd(a,b)=1.
Then apply the division algorithm to get a=qb+ra=qb+ra=qb+rinducting on deg⁡a+deg⁡b\deg a+\deg bdega+degb, apply Bezout’s lemma to b,rb,rb,r and rearrange the terms; in the case r=0r=0r=0, bbb must be constant to have gcd(a,b)=1\mathrm{gcd}(a,b)=1gcd(a,b)=1.

  • Every ideal polynomial ring I⊲F[x]I\lhd\mathbb F[x]I⊲F[x] is generated by one element; that is, ∃k(x)∈F[x]:I=kF[x]\exists k(x)\in \mathbb{F}[x]:I=k\mathbb{F}[x]∃k(x)∈F[x]:I=kF[x]

Proof: let kkk be the least-degreed, non-zero polynomial in III, then every element in III must be a multiple of it; otherwise, the division algorithm would give a non-zero remainder rrr.
r∈Ir \in Ir∈I by closure, and deg⁡r<deg⁡k\deg r<\deg kdegr<degk; this is contrary to the choice of kkk.

Matrix Polynomials

  • Polynomials can be evaluated on matrices by replacing xxx with a matrix AAA: f(A)=akAk+⋯+a1A+a0If(A)=a_kA^k+\cdots+a_1A+a_0If(A)=ak​Ak+⋯+a1​A+a0​Iand this gives the ring homomorphism called evaluation map: EA:F[x]→Fn×n, f↦f(A)E_A:\mathbb F[x]\to \mathbb{F}^{n \times n}, \, f \mapsto f(A)EA​:F[x]→Fn×n,f↦f(A)

  • Eliminating polynomials of A∈Fn×nA \in \mathbb{F}^{n \times n}A∈Fn×n are polynomials that evaluate to 000 at AAA.

    • All finite-dimensional matrices have eliminating polynomials, as the infinite set {A,A2,⋯ }\{A,A^2,\cdots\}{A,A2,⋯} cannot be linearly independent in a finite-dimensional vector space of matrices.

  • The minimal polynomial of A:mA(x)A:m_A(x)A:mA​(x) is a monic eliminating polynomial of the least degree.

  • The minimal polynomial divides all eliminating polynomials (and hence is unique).

    • Hence the minimal polynomial is unique: any two minimal polynomials divide each other, so they must be the same because they are monic.

Proof: the first isomorphism theorem guarantees {p:p(A)=0n×n}=ker⁡EA\{ p:p(A)=0_{n\times n} \}=\ker E_A{p:p(A)=0n×n​}=kerEA​ to be an ideal polynomial ring. Hence it is generated by the lowest-degree element, namely the minimal polynomial.

Eigenvalues and Polynomials

  • The eigenvalues and minimal/characteristic polynomials of a linear map is those of its matrix (under any basis).
  • Minimal and characteristic polynomials of linear map TTT are invariant under basis changes, so they are well-defined.

Proof: fix a change-of-basis matrix P∈GLn(F)P \in GL_{n}(\mathbb{F})P∈GLn​(F), where under the new basis, TTT has matrix C=P−1APC=P^{-1}APC=P−1AP.

Minimal: Any polynomial fff has f(A)=0  ⟺  f(C)=P−1f(A)P=0f(A)=0\iff f(C)=P^{-1}f(A)P=0f(A)=0⟺f(C)=P−1f(A)P=0 by invertibility of PPP. Then AAA and CCC have the same eliminating, hence minimal, polynomials.

Characteristic: note that det⁡(P−1AP)=det⁡(P−1)det⁡(A)det⁡(P)=det⁡(A)\det (P^{-1}AP)=\det (P^{-1})\det (A)\det (P)=\det (A)det(P−1AP)=det(P−1)det(A)det(P)=det(A), so the characteristics χA\chi_{A}χA​ and χC{\chi}_{C}χC​ are equal: χA=det⁡(A−λI)=det⁡(P−1(A−λI)P)=det⁡(P−1AP−λI)=χC\chi_{A}=\det(A-\lambda I)=\det(P^{-1}(A-\lambda I)P)=\det(P^{-1}AP-\lambda I)={\chi}_{C}χA​=det(A−λI)=det(P−1(A−λI)P)=det(P−1AP−λI)=χC​

  • Eigenvalues of AAA are the same as roots of mA(x)m_A(x)mA​(x).

Proof: (⇒\Rightarrow⇒) eigenvalue λ\lambdaλ satisfies Av=λvAv=\lambda vAv=λv for some eigenvector v≠0v\ne \bf 0v=0,
so mA(λ)v=mA(A)v=0m_A(\lambda)v=m_A(A)v=\bf 0mA​(λ)v=mA​(A)v=0 by linearity, hence mA(λ)=0m_A(\lambda)=0mA​(λ)=0

(⇐\Leftarrow⇐) root λ\lambdaλ of mA(x)m_A(x)mA​(x) gives mA=(x−λ)g(x)m_A=(x-\lambda)g(x)mA​=(x−λ)g(x) for some g:g(A)≠0g:g(A)\ne0g:g(A)=0 (by minimality of mAm_AmA​),
Take w:g(A)w≠0w:g(A)w\ne \bf 0w:g(A)w=0, then g(A)wg(A)wg(A)w is an eigenvector of AAA with eigenvalue λ\lambdaλ: (A−λI)(g(A)w)=mA(A)w=0(A-\lambda I)(g(A)w)=m_{A}(A)w=\mathbf{0}(A−λI)(g(A)w)=mA​(A)w=0

Quotient Spaces

Definition

  • Given vector space VVV and subspace U≤VU\le VU≤V, the quotient space is the vector space formed by the set of the cosets of UUU: V/U≡{v+U:v∈V}, where v+U≡{v+u:u∈U}(v1+U)+(v2+U)≡(v1+v2)+Uk(v+U)≡(kv)+U\begin{align*}& V / U \equiv\{v+U:v\in V\},\text{ where }v+U\equiv\{v+u:u\in U\}\\ \\&(v_1+U)+(v_2+U)\equiv(v_1+v_2)+U\\ &k(v+U)\equiv(kv)+U\end{align*}​V/U≡{v+U:v∈V}, where v+U≡{v+u:u∈U}(v1​+U)+(v2​+U)≡(v1​+v2​)+Uk(v+U)≡(kv)+U​

Quotients and Direct Sums

Big idea: the quotient space is isomorphic with a direct sum.

  • The quotient space is “generated” by the basis vectors of VVV that is not in UUU: given a basis E⊂U\mathcal E\subset UE⊂U and extend it to F⊂V\mathcal F\subset VF⊂V, then
    Bˉ≡{b+U:b∈F/E} is a basis for V/U\bar{\mathcal B}\equiv \{b+U:b\in\mathcal F/\mathcal E\}\text{ is a basis for } V/UBˉ≡{b+U:b∈F/E} is a basis for V/U
  • Conversely, a basis Bˉ={bk+U}\bar{\mathcal B}=\{b_k+U\}Bˉ={bk​+U} of V/UV/UV/U can join a basis E⊂U\mathcal E\subset UE⊂U to become a basis of VVV: {bk}∪E is a basis of V\{b_k\}\cup \mathcal E \text{ is a basis of }V{bk​}∪E is a basis of V
  • Hence, with W=⟨{bk}⟩W=\langle\{b_k\}\rangleW=⟨{bk​}⟩ forms a direct sum with UUU: W⊕U=VW≅V/U\begin{align*}&W\oplus U=V\\ &W\cong V/U\end{align*}​W⊕U=VW≅V/U​

First Isomorphism Theorem (for vector spaces)

  • First isomorphism theorem: given a linear map T:V→WT:V\to WT:V→W, the following is a vector space isomorphism: Tˉ: V/ker⁡T→Im Tv+ker⁡T↦T(v)\begin{align*}\bar T:\ &V / \ker T\to \text{Im }T\\&v+\ker T \mapsto T(v)\end{align*}Tˉ: ​V/kerT→Im Tv+kerT↦T(v)​

Proof: FIT for groups gives Tˉ\bar TTˉ is a isomorphism of groups, and verifying Tˉ\bar TTˉ compatible with scalar multiplication completes the proof.

  • The rank-nullity theorem is an immediate corollary: in a finite-dimensional vector space, Tˉ\bar TTˉ being an isomorphism guarantees that dim⁡V−dim⁡ker⁡T=dim⁡(V/ker⁡T)=dim⁡Im T\dim V-\dim\ker T=\dim(V/\ker T)=\dim\text{Im }TdimV−dimkerT=dim(V/kerT)=dimIm T

Maps between Quotients

  • Given a linear map T:V→W,A⊆V,B⊆WT:V\to W, A\subseteq V, B\subseteq WT:V→W,A⊆V,B⊆W, we can construct Tˉ: V/A→W/Bv+A→T(v)+B\begin{align*}\bar T: \ &V/A\to W/B\\ & v+A\to T(v)+B\end{align*}Tˉ: ​V/A→W/Bv+A→T(v)+B​
  • Tˉ\bar{T}Tˉ is linear and well-defined   ⟺  \iff⟺ T(A)⊆BT(A)\subseteq BT(A)⊆B.

Proof: (⇒\Rightarrow⇒) given well-defined Tˉ,a∈A\bar T, a\in ATˉ,a∈A, since Tˉ\bar{T}Tˉ is linear, Tˉ(a+A)=Tˉ(0V/A)=0W/B=B,\bar T(a+A)=\bar T(0_{V/A})=0_{W/B}=B,Tˉ(a+A)=Tˉ(0V/A​)=0W/B​=B,
But by definition of Tˉ\bar{T}Tˉ, Tˉ(a+A)=T(a)+B\bar{T}(a+A)=T(a)+BTˉ(a+A)=T(a)+B. So T(a)∈BT(a)\in BT(a)∈B.

(⇐\Leftarrow⇐) given T(A)⊆BT(A)\subseteq BT(A)⊆B, then for any v,w∈V:T(v)−T(w)∈Bv,w\in V:T(v)-T(w)\in Bv,w∈V:T(v)−T(w)∈B,
so different representations of the same coset v+A=w+A∈V/Av+A=w+A \in V/Av+A=w+A∈V/A are mapped to the same coset T(v)+B=T(w)+B∈W/BT(v)+B=T(w)+B\in W/BT(v)+B=T(w)+B∈W/B.

Decomposing Maps with Quotients

  • Outline: given the definitions in the section above, we can break down TTT into (1) T∣A(1)\ T|_{A}(1) T∣A​ mapping A→BA\to BA→B, and (2) Tˉ(2)\ \bar{T}(2) Tˉ mapping V/A→W/BV/A\to W/BV/A→W/B.  A∗undefined   T∣A  B(1)↑∗undefined    T    ↑ V∗undefined    T    W(2)↓∗undefined    T    ↓ A∗∗undefined   T    B∗≅∗undefined        ≅V/A undefined  Tˉ    W/B\begin{align*} &\,A \hphantom{^*}\xRightarrow{\,\,\,T|_{A}\,\,}B\\ (1)&\uparrow \hphantom{^*\xRightarrow{\,\,\,\,T\,\,\,\,}} \uparrow\\ &\,V \hphantom{^*}\xRightarrow{\,\,\,\,T\,\,\,\,}W\\ (2)&\downarrow \hphantom{^*\xRightarrow{\,\,\,\,T\,\,\,\,}} \downarrow\\ &\,A^{*}\hphantom{^*\xRightarrow{\,\,\,T\,\,\,\,}}B^{*} \\ &\cong \hphantom{^*\xRightarrow{\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,}} \cong\\ V& / A \,\xRightarrow{\,\,\bar{T}\,\,\,\,} W / B\\ \end{align*}(1)(2)V​A∗T∣A​​B↑∗T​↑V∗T​W↓∗T​↓A∗∗T​B∗≅∗​≅/ATˉ​W/B​
  • Defining the bases:

Get bases BA,B\mathcal{B}_{A,B}BA,B​ of A,BA,BA,B.
Extend them to bases BV,W\mathcal{B}_{V,W}BV,W​ of V,WV,WV,W.
A∗A^*A∗ has basis BA∗=BV∖BA\mathcal{B}_{A^*}=\mathcal{B}_{V}\setminus \mathcal{B}_{A}BA∗​=BV​∖BA​, similar for B∗B^*B∗.
The induced basis of V/AV / AV/A is BˉA∗={b+A:b∈BA∗}\mathcal{\bar{B}}_{A^*}=\{b+A:b\in \mathcal{B}_{A^*}\}BˉA∗​={b+A:b∈BA∗​}, similar for W/BW / BW/B. This gives the isomorphisms V/A≅A∗,W/B≅B∗V / A \cong A^{*}, W / B \cong B^*V/A≅A∗,W/B≅B∗.

  • (1)(1)(1) The component of TTT mapping A→BA\to BA→B:

Define T∣A:A→BT|_A:A\to BT∣A​:A→B to be TTT restricted to AAA, with matrix BB[T∣A]BA{}_{\mathcal B_B}[T|_A]_{\mathcal B_A}BB​​[T∣A​]BA​​.
As a map T∣A:A→WT|_{A}:A \to WT∣A​:A→W, its matrix is BW[T∣A]BA=(BB[T∣A]BA0){}_{\mathcal{B}_{W}}[T|_{A}]_{\mathcal{B}_{A}}=\begin{pmatrix} {}_{\mathcal B_B}[T|_A]_{\mathcal B_A} \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}BW​​[T∣A​]BA​​=(BB​​[T∣A​]BA​​0​)where the lower half is 000 since they represent the components that T∣A(BA)=T(BA)T|_{A}(\mathcal{B}_{A})=T(\mathcal{B}_{A})T∣A​(BA​)=T(BA​) has in terms of BB∗\mathcal B_{B^*}BB∗​, of which there is none.

  • (2)(2)(2) The component mapping V/A→W/BV/A\to W/BV/A→W/B:

We define Tˉ\bar TTˉ as in the previous section, with the matrix BˉB∗[Tˉ]BˉA∗_{\mathcal{\bar{B}}_{B^{*}}}[\bar T]_{\mathcal {\bar{B}}_{A^{*}}}BˉB∗​​[Tˉ]BˉA∗​​.
Under Tˉ\bar{T}Tˉ, the basis (a∗+A)∈BˉA∗(a^{*}+A) \in \bar{\mathcal{B}}_{A^{*}}(a∗+A)∈BˉA∗​ is mapped to (b∗+B)(b^{*}+B)(b∗+B) for some b∗∈B∗b^{*} \in B^{*}b∗∈B∗. By definition of Tˉ\bar{T}Tˉ, T∣A∗(a∗)T|_{A^*}(a^{*})T∣A∗​(a∗) must have the form b∗+bb^{*} +bb∗+b for some b∈Bb \in Bb∈B.
Hence T∣A∗T|_{A^{*}}T∣A∗​ has the matrix MT∣A∗=(T∣A∗(BA∗) in terms of BBT∣A∗(BA∗) in terms of BB∗)=(∗ BˉB∗[Tˉ]BˉA∗)M_{T|_{A^{*}}}=\begin{pmatrix} \text{$T|_{A^*}(\mathcal{B}_{A^{*}})$ in terms of }\mathcal{B}_{B} \\ \text{$T|_{A^*}(\mathcal{B}_{A^{*}})$ in terms of }\mathcal{B}_{B^{*}} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} * \\ \ _{\mathcal{\bar{B}}_{B^{*}}}[\bar T]_{\mathcal {\bar{B}}_{A^{*}}} \end{pmatrix}MT∣A∗​​=(T∣A∗​(BA∗​) in terms of BB​T∣A∗​(BA∗​) in terms of BB∗​​)=(∗ BˉB∗​​[Tˉ]BˉA∗​​​)

  • The whole map put back together:

The matrix of TTT under the bases BV,BW\mathcal B_V,\mathcal B_WBV​,BW​ is the concatenation of the two components: BW[T]BV=([T∣A][T∣A∗])=(BB[T∣A]BA∗0BˉB∗[Tˉ]BˉA∗)_{\mathcal B_W}[T]_{\mathcal B_V}=\begin{pmatrix} [T|_{A}] & [T|_{A^{*}}] \end{pmatrix} =\begin{pmatrix}{}_{\mathcal B_B}[T|_A]_{\mathcal B_A} & \ast \\ 0 & _{\mathcal{\bar{B}}_{B^{*}}}[\bar T]_{\mathcal {\bar{B}}_{A^{*}}} \end{pmatrix}BW​​[T]BV​​=([T∣A​]​[T∣A∗​]​)=(BB​​[T∣A​]BA​​0​∗BˉB∗​​[Tˉ]BˉA∗​​​)which is block upper triangular.

Triangular Forms and Cayley-Hamilton Theorem

Invariant Subspaces

  • Given U≤V,T:V→VU\le V, T:V\to VU≤V,T:V→V, then UUU is called T\mathbf{T}T-invariant if T(U)⊆UT(U)\subseteq UT(U)⊆U.
    • Furthermore, by linearity UUU is also invariant under any polynomial of TTT.
    • Hence UUU induces the map TˉU:V/U→V/U;  v+U→T(v)+U\bar{T}_{U}:V / U\to V / U;\,\,v+U\to T(v)+UTˉU​:V/U→V/U;v+U→T(v)+U.
  • For T:V→VT: V\to VT:V→V, and U≤VU\le VU≤V invariant under TTT, there is χT=χT∣U⋅χTˉ\chi_{T}=\chi_{T|_U}\cdot\chi_{\bar{T}}χT​=χT∣U​​⋅χTˉ​

Proof: apply the result from the previous section on TTT and UUU to get a matrix MT=(MT∣U∗0MTˉ)M_{T}=\begin{pmatrix}M_{T|_{U}} & \ast \\ 0 & M_{\bar{T}}\end{pmatrix}MT​=(MT∣U​​0​∗MTˉ​​). Evaluate the LHS as det⁡(MT−λI)\det(M_{T}-\lambda I)det(MT​−λI) gives the equality.

Upper-Triangular Matrices

  • Given T:V→VT: V\to VT:V→V, if the characteristic polynomial of TTT have all-linear factors, there is a basis under which it is upper-triangular.

Proof: induct on the dimension of TTT; for 1×11\times 11×1 matrices, the result is trivial.

Inductive step: take any eigenvalue λ\lambdaλ of TTT and (one of) its corresponding eigenvector vvv, then the subspace U=⟨v⟩U=\langle v \rangleU=⟨v⟩ is invariant under TTT.
So we can find a basis where MT=(MT∣U=(λ)∗0MTˉ)M_{T}=\begin{pmatrix}M_{T|_{U}}=(\lambda) & \ast \\ 0 & M_{\bar{T}}\end{pmatrix}MT​=(MT∣U​​=(λ)0​∗MTˉ​​). Since χT=χT∣U⋅χTˉ\chi_{T}=\chi_{T|_U}\cdot\chi_{\bar{T}}χT​=χT∣U​​⋅χTˉ​, χTˉ\chi_{\bar{T}}χTˉ​ must also be a product of linear factors, so the induction hypothesis makes the bottom right matrix upper-triangular, so the entire MTM_{T}MT​ is upper-triangular. This completes the induction.

  • For upper-triangular matrix AAA with diagonal elements λ1,…,λn\lambda_{1},\dots ,\lambda_{n}λ1​,…,λn​, its characteristic polynomial is eliminating; that is, χA(A)=∏i=1n(A−λiI)=0n×n\chi_{A}(A)=\prod^{n}_{i=1}(A-\lambda_{i} I)=0_{n \times n}χA​(A)=i=1∏n​(A−λi​I)=0n×n​

Proof: take a basis {v1,…,vn}\{v_1,\dots,v_{n}\}{v1​,…,vn​} of Fn\mathbb{F}^nFn, so AAA represents a linear map Fn→Fn\mathbb{F}^{n}\to \mathbb{F}^nFn→Fn under that basis.
Then by looking at the entries in (A−λkI)(A-\lambda_{k}I)(A−λk​I), note that the first kkk columns are non-000 only in the first (k−1)(k-1)(k−1) entries.
Hence inductively, Im(A−λnI)⊆⟨v1,…vn−2, vn−1⟩Im[(A−λn−1I)(A−λnI)]⊆⟨v1,…,vn−2⟩...Im[(A−λ1I)⋯(A−λn−1I)(A−λnIundefinedχA(A))]⊆⟨∅⟩=∅\begin{align*} \mathrm{Im}(A-\lambda_{n}I) &\subseteq \langle v_{1}, \dots v_{n-2},\,v_{n-1} \rangle\\ \mathrm{Im}[(A-\lambda_{n-1}I)(A-\lambda_{n}I)]& \subseteq\langle v_{1}, \dots, v_{n-2} \rangle\\ &\text{...}\\ \mathrm{Im}[(\underbrace{A-\lambda_{1}I)\cdots (A-\lambda_{n-1}I)(A-\lambda_{n}I}_{\chi_{A}(A)})]&\subseteq\langle \emptyset \rangle=\emptyset \end{align*}Im(A−λn​I)Im[(A−λn−1​I)(A−λn​I)]Im[(χA​(A)A−λ1​I)⋯(A−λn−1​I)(A−λn​I​​)]​⊆⟨v1​,…vn−2​,vn−1​⟩⊆⟨v1​,…,vn−2​⟩...⊆⟨∅⟩=∅​
So χA(A)\chi_{A}(A)χA​(A) must be the zero matrix.

Cayley-Hamilton theorem

  • Cayley-Hamilton theorem: the characteristic is eliminating for any generic linear map TTT with matrix A∈Fn×nA\in \mathbb{F}^{n \times n}A∈Fn×n: χT(T)=χA(A)=0\chi_{T}(T)=\chi_{A}(A)=0χT​(T)=χA​(A)=0and so mA∣χAm_{A}|\chi_{A}mA​∣χA​.

Proof: we reduce AAA to an upper triangular matrix, and use the uniqueness of the characteristic polynomial.

In the algebraic extension Fˉ\mathbb{\bar{F}}Fˉ of F\mathbb{F}F, we can always factor χA\chi_{A}χA​ into linear factors, so AAA can be made upper-triangular in Fˉn×n\mathbb{\bar{F}}^{n\times n}Fˉn×n, say there is P∈Fˉn×n:P−1APP\in \mathbb{\bar{F}}^{n\times n}:P^{-1}APP∈Fˉn×n:P−1AP is upper-triangular.

Then by the previous result, χP−1AP(P−1AP)=0\chi_{P^{-1}AP}(P^{-1}AP)=0χP−1AP​(P−1AP)=0. Since the characteristic polynomial is invariant under different bases, this is the CP of TTT, and it eliminates TTT.

The fact that we worked in Fˉ[x]\mathbb{\bar{F}}[x]Fˉ[x] does not change the polynomial–it must have been in F[x]\mathbb{F}[x]F[x] in the first place. Think (x−i)(x+i)(x-i)(x+i)(x−i)(x+i) and x2+1x^2+1x2+1: say we found the first as χP−1AP\chi_{P^{-1}AP}χP−1AP​ in C[x]\mathbb{C}[x]C[x], but it equals the second which is in R[x]\mathbb{R}[x]R[x].

  • Corollary: the minimal is written in distinct, monic, and irreducible factors, then the characteristic must have the same factors (to an equal-or-higher power): [mT=f1k1…fnkn]⟹[χT=±f1l1…fnln]    (li≥ki)[m_{T}=f_{1}^{k_{1}}\dots f_{n}^{k_{n}}] \Longrightarrow [\chi_{T}=\pm f_{1}^{l_{1}}\dots f_{n}^{l_{n}}] \,\,\,\,(l_{i} \ge k_{i})[mT​=f1k1​​…fnkn​​]⟹[χT​=±f1l1​​…fnln​​](li​≥ki​)and in particular, χT\chi_{T}χT​ has linear factorization   ⟺  \iff⟺ mTm_{T}mT​ has linear factorization.

Proof: the factors must be the same (with no additional ones) since the minimal and characteristic polynomials have the same roots in Fˉ\mathbb{\bar{F}}Fˉ.
The ±\pm± comes from χT\chi_{T}χT​ having (−1)dim⁡V(-1)^{\dim V}(−1)dimV as the leading coefficient.

The Primary Decomposition Theorem

Proof of the PDT

  • In a finite dimensional vector space VVV with a linear map T:V→V,f∈F[x]:f(T)=0T:V\to V, f \in \mathbb{F}[x]: f(T)=0T:V→V,f∈F[x]:f(T)=0, and it can be factorized as f(x)=a(x)b(x), gcd⁡(a,b)=1f(x)=a(x)b(x),\,\gcd(a,b)=1f(x)=a(x)b(x),gcd(a,b)=1, then V=ker⁡a(T) ⊕ ker⁡b(T)V=\ker a(T)\,\oplus\,\ker b(T)V=kera(T)⊕kerb(T)

Proof:
Spanning: Bezout’s lemma for polynomials give s,t∈F[x]:as+bt=1s,t\in \mathbb{F}[x]: as+bt=1s,t∈F[x]:as+bt=1.
Write A=a(T)A=a(T)A=a(T), and similarly B,S,T,FB,S,T,FB,S,T,F.
Then ∀v∈V: ASv+BTv=v   (∗)\forall v\in V:\ ASv+BTv=v \ \ \ (*)∀v∈V: ASv+BTv=v   (∗)Since F=BA=AB=0F=BA=AB=0F=BA=AB=0, we have B(ASv)=(BA)(Sv)=0B(ASv)=(BA)(Sv)=0B(ASv)=(BA)(Sv)=0, so ASv∈ker⁡BASv\in \ker BASv∈kerB, similarly BTv∈ker⁡ABTv\in \ker ABTv∈kerA.
Now (∗)(*)(∗) is a decomposition of vvv in terms of ker⁡A+ker⁡B\ker A +\ker BkerA+kerB.

Disjointness: any v∈ker⁡A∩ker⁡Bv\in \ker A\cap \ker Bv∈kerA∩kerB would make LHS\mathrm{LHS}LHS of (∗) 0(*) \ \mathbf{0}(∗) 0, so RHS=v=0\mathrm{RHS}=v=\mathbf{0}RHS=v=0 as well.

  • In particular, if f=mTf=m_{T}f=mT​, a,ba,ba,b monic, then a=mT∣ker⁡a(T), b=mT∣ker⁡b(T)a=m_{T|\ker a(T)}, \ b=m_{T|\ker b(T)}a=mT∣kera(T)​, b=mT∣kerb(T)​.

Proof: a,ba,ba,b eliminate T∣ker⁡A,BT|_{\ker A,B}T∣kerA,B​ respectively, so they are divisible by the minimal polynomials.

Write m1=mT∣ker⁡A,m2=mT∣ker⁡Bm_{1}=m_{T|\ker A}, m_{2}=m_{T|\ker B}m1​=mT∣kerA​,m2​=mT∣kerB​,
Then at the same time, the product m1m2m_{1}m_{2}m1​m2​ eliminates TTT:
for any v∈Vv\in Vv∈V decomposed into w1+w2,w1∈ker⁡A,w2∈ker⁡Bw_{1}+w_{2},w_{1}\in \ker A, w_{2}\in \ker Bw1​+w2​,w1​∈kerA,w2​∈kerB, [m1(T)m2(T)]v=m2(T)[m1(T)w1]+m1(T)[m2(T)w2]=0+0=0\begin{align*} [m_{1}(T)m_{2}(T)]v&=m_{2}(T)[m_{1}(T)w_{1}] + m_{1}(T)[m_{2}(T)w_{2}]\\ &=0+0 = 0 \end{align*}[m1​(T)m2​(T)]v​=m2​(T)[m1​(T)w1​]+m1​(T)[m2​(T)w2​]=0+0=0​So f=abf=abf=ab, being the minimal polynomial of TTT, divides m1m2m_{1}m_{2}m1​m2​.
Hence a=m1,b=m2a=m_{1}, b=m_{2}a=m1​,b=m2​.

  • Primary Decomposition Theorem: given linear map T:V→VT: V\to VT:V→V, and decomposition of its minimal polynomial mT=f1k1…fnkn,m_{T}=f_{1}^{k_{1}}\dots f_{n}^{k_{n}},mT​=f1k1​​…fnkn​​, all distinct, monic, and irreducible, then if we write Wi=ker⁡(fiki(T))W_{i}=\ker (f_{i}^{k_{i}}(T))Wi​=ker(fiki​​(T)), there is:
    • V=W1 ⊕ ⋯⊕ Wn;V=W_{1}\,\oplus\,\cdots\oplus\, W_{n};V=W1​⊕⋯⊕Wn​;
    • WiW_iWi​ is TTT-invariant: T(Wi)⊂Wi;T(W_{i})\subset W_{i};T(Wi​)⊂Wi​;
    • mT∣Wi=fiki.m_{T|_{W_{i}}}=f_{i}^{k_{i}}.mT∣Wi​​​=fiki​​.

Proof: induct on nnn (the number of terms) using the previous two results.

For invariance, take any v∈Wiv \in W_{i}v∈Wi​. Due to TTT commuting with any polynomial of itself, fiki(T)(Tv)=T(fiki(T)v)=T(0)=0f_{i}^{k_{i}}(T)(Tv)=T(f_{{i} }^{k_{i}}(T)v)=T(0)=0fiki​​(T)(Tv)=T(fiki​​(T)v)=T(0)=0so Tv∈ker⁡(fiki(T))=WiTv \in \ker(f_{i}^{k_{i}}(T))=W_{i}Tv∈ker(fiki​​(T))=Wi​.

Reducibility Corollaries of the PDT

  • Using this direct sum ⨁iWi\bigoplus_{i}W_{i}⨁i​Wi​, use the bases BiB_{i}Bi​ of WiW_{i}Wi​ to define a basis B=∪iBiB=\cup_{i} B_{i}B=∪i​Bi​ of VVV, then TTT has a block-diagonal matrix under BBB: B[T]B=diag(Bi[T∣Wi]Bi)_{B}[T]_{B}=\text{diag}( _{Bi}[T|_{Wi}]_{Bi})B​[T]B​=diag(Bi​[T∣Wi​]Bi​)
  • mTm_{T}mT​ can be reduced to linear, monic factors fi=(x−λi):∏ifiki=mT  ⟺  f_{i}=(x-\lambda_{i}):\prod_{i} f_{i}^{k_{i}}=m_{T} \ifffi​=(x−λi​):∏i​fiki​​=mT​⟺ the map TTT is triangularizable.

Proof: triangularizability   ⟺  \iff⟺ linear factorization of χT\chi_{T}χT​   ⟺  \iff⟺ linear factorization of mTm_{T}mT​. For the second equivalence, see the corollary of Cayley-Hamilton.

  • All the factors of mTm_{T}mT​ are unique and linear   ⟺  \iff⟺ the map is diagonalizable.

Proof:
(⇐\Leftarrow⇐) if λ1,…,λr≤n\lambda_{1},\dots,\lambda_{r \le n}λ1​,…,λr≤n​ are the distinct factors in the diagonal matrix representation of TTT, then mT=∏i(x−λi)m_{T}=\prod_{i}(x-\lambda_{i})mT​=∏i​(x−λi​) eliminates TTT.

(⇒\Rightarrow⇒) if fi=(x−λi)f_{i}=(x-\lambda_{i})fi​=(x−λi​) are all unique, then PDT gives a direct sum ⨁iEλi\bigoplus_{i}E_{\lambda i}⨁i​Eλi​, where Eλi=ker⁡(T−λiI)E_{\lambda i}=\ker (T-\lambda_{i} I)Eλi​=ker(T−λi​I) is the eigenspace of λi\lambda_{i}λi​.
Any basis Bi⊂EλiB_{i}\subset E_{\lambda i}Bi​⊂Eλi​ gives the diagonal block [T∣Eλi]=λiI[T|_{E_{\lambda i}}]=\lambda_{i}I[T∣Eλi​​]=λi​I, so their union B=∪iBiB=\cup_{i} B_{i}B=∪i​Bi​ gives a diagonal B[T]B{}_{B}[T]_{B}B​[T]B​.

Jordan Normal Form

I confess that I have no idea what the 2022 lecture notes are talking about. I used the webnotes from Northwestern University.

If you are reading this solely for exam-prep, concepts like Jordan chains are NOT mentioned in the lecture notes, so don’t quote them in the exams without giving a definition.

Big idea: JNFs describe linear transformations by showing what they do to their eigenspaces.

Nilpotent Maps

  • A linear map T:V→VT:V\to VT:V→V is nilpotent if ∃n:Tn=0\exists n:T^n=0∃n:Tn=0where 000 is the map V→{0}V \to \{ 0 \}V→{0}.
  • All nilpotent maps have minimal polynomial mT(x)=xmm_{T}(x)=x^mmT​(x)=xm.

Proof: xnx^nxn eliminates the map, the minimal polynomials must divide into it.

  • For nilpotent map TTT with mT(x)=xmm_{T}(x)=x^mmT​(x)=xm, there must be strict inclusions ker⁡(T)⊊ker⁡(T2)⊊⋯⊊ker⁡(Tm)=V\ker(T)\subsetneq\ker(T^{2})\subsetneq \cdots\subsetneq \ker(T^m)=Vker(T)⊊ker(T2)⊊⋯⊊ker(Tm)=V

Proof: if there is an equality ker⁡Tk=ker⁡Tk+1\ker T^{k}=\ker T^{k+1}kerTk=kerTk+1, then Tk+sv=0  ⟺  Tk+1(Ts−1v)=0  ⟺  Ts−1v∈ker⁡Tk+1=ker⁡Tk  ⟺  Tk+s−1v=0  ⟺  ⋯  ⟺  Tkv=0,\begin{align*} T^{k+s}v = 0 &\iff T^{k+1}(T^{s-1}v)=0\\ &\iff T^{s-1}v\in \ker T^{k+1}=\ker T^k\\ &\iff T^{k+s-1}v=0\\ &\iff \cdots\\ &\iff T^k v=0, \end{align*}Tk+sv=0​⟺Tk+1(Ts−1v)=0⟺Ts−1v∈kerTk+1=kerTk⟺Tk+s−1v=0⟺⋯⟺Tkv=0,​but then taking k+s=mk+s=mk+s=m means ker⁡Tk=V\ker T^k=VkerTk=V, contrary to the definition of mT(x)=xmm_{T}(x)=x^mmT​(x)=xm as the minimal polynomial.

  • If TTT has eigenvalue λ\lambdaλ, the generalized eigenspace of λ\lambdaλ is defined to beFλ={v∈V:(T−λI)kv=0   for some k≥1}F_{\lambda}=\{ v\in V :(T-\lambda I)^{k}v=0\,\,\text{ for some }k \ge 1\}Fλ​={v∈V:(T−λI)kv=0 for some k≥1} Also, vvv is called a generalized eigenvector. For contrast, “ordinary eigenvectors/values” refer to the usual v,λ:λv=Tvv,\lambda: \lambda v=Tvv,λ:λv=Tv.

Jordan Blocks and Jordan Normal Forms

  • An nnn-dimensional Jordan block of (eigenvalue) λ\lambdaλ is the k×kk \times kk×k matrix of the form Jk(λ)=(λ1λ1⋱⋱λ1λ)k×kJ_{k}(\lambda)= \begin{pmatrix} \lambda & 1 & & & \\ & \lambda & 1 & & \\ && \ddots & \ddots & \\ &&& \lambda & 1 \\ &&&&\lambda \end{pmatrix}_{k \times k}Jk​(λ)=⎝⎛​λ​1λ​1⋱​⋱λ​1λ​⎠⎞​k×k​
  • The Jordan Normal Form (JNF) of a linear map TTT is a matrix representation of it under some basis B\mathcal{B}B, which is block diagonal, with each block being a Jordan block: B[T]B=(Jk1(λ1)0⋱0Jks(λs))_{\mathcal B}[T]_{\mathcal B}=\begin{pmatrix}J_{k_{1}}(\lambda_{1}) & &0 \\ & \ddots \\ 0&&J_{k_{s}}(\lambda_{s}) \end{pmatrix}B​[T]B​=⎝⎛​Jk1​​(λ1​)0​⋱​0Jks​​(λs​)​⎠⎞​where λ1…s\lambda_{1 \dots s}λ1…s​ are the (not necessarily distinct) eigenvalues of TTT.
  • Goal: a map TTT can always be put into JNF, if its minimal polynomial can be factorized into linear factors (not necessarily distinct).
    • In particular, TTT in complex vector spaces always have JNFs.

Proof: JNF on Generalized Eigenspaces

Big idea: TTT restricted to a single generalized eigenspace can be represented with a JNF. We would then glue them together into a larger JNF that represents the unrestricted map TTT.

  • For a map TTT with eigenvalue λ\lambdaλ, and a generalized eigenvector v∈Fλv\in F_{\lambda}v∈Fλ​, S=T−λIS=T-\lambda IS=T−λI, then taking k=min⁡{k:Skv=0}k=\min\{k:S^{k}v=0\}k=min{k:Skv=0} gives the Jordan chain c(v)={Sk−1v,…,S2v,Sv,v}c(v)=\{S^{k-1}v,\dots,S^{2}v,Sv,v\}c(v)={Sk−1v,…,S2v,Sv,v}and we will treat it as an ordered set when used as a basis.

  • A Jordan chain c(v)c(v)c(v) is linearly independent and hence is the basis of C(v)=⟨c(v)⟩C(v)=\langle c(v) \rangleC(v)=⟨c(v)⟩.

Proof: if ∑i=0k−1aiSiv=0\sum_{i=0}^{k-1}a_{i}S^{i}v=0∑i=0k−1​ai​Siv=0, then left-applying Sk−1S^{k-1}Sk−1 gives a0Sk−1v=0a_{0}S^{k-1}v=0a0​Sk−1v=0, so a0=0a_{0}=0a0​=0.
Again, left-applying Sk−2S^{k-2}Sk−2 now gives a1=0a_{1}=0a1​=0, etc. So all of aia_{i}ai​ must be 000, and the chain is linearly independent.

  • The generalized eigenspace FλF_{\lambda}Fλ​ has a basis Bλ=∪ic(vi)B_{\lambda}=\cup_{i}c(v_{i})Bλ​=∪i​c(vi​), where c(vi)c(v_{i})c(vi​) are Jordan chains in FλF_{\lambda}Fλ​.

Proof: take the longest Jordan chain c(v1)c(v_{1})c(v1​) in FλF_{\lambda}Fλ​, and if its span does not cover the entire generalized eigenspace, i.e. C(v1)=⟨c(v1)⟩≠FλC(v_{1})=\langle c(v_{1}) \rangle \ne F_{\lambda}C(v1​)=⟨c(v1​)⟩=Fλ​, now use more chains to span its “complement” O∗:Fλ=O(v1) ⊕O∗O^{*}:F_{\lambda}=O(v_{1})\,\oplus O^*O∗:Fλ​=O(v1​)⊕O∗.
Repeat the process for O∗O^*O∗ in finding the longest Jordan chain c(v2)c(v_{2})c(v2​), and taking complements, etc.

Eventually the chains will exhaust the dimensions of FλF_{\lambda}Fλ​ and give a basis of it, namely Bλ=∪i c(vi)B_{\lambda}=\cup_{i}\ c(v_{i})Bλ​=∪i​ c(vi​). It is indeed a basis, as BλB_{\lambda}Bλ​ is linearly independent because each chain is linearly independent within, and different chains are from subspaces that form a direct sum.

  • T∣C(v)T|_{C(v)}T∣C(v)​ under the basis c(v)c(v)c(v) is represented by the Jordan block Jk(λ)J_{k}(\lambda)Jk​(λ).

Proof: note that the iiith column represent the image of the iiith basis vector, which is Si−1vS^{i-1}vSi−1v.
Since it is mapped to λSi−1v+Siv\lambda S^{i-1} v+S^{i}vλSi−1v+Siv, the column is (…,0,1,λith,0,… )t(\dots,0,1,\underset{i\text{th}}{\lambda},0,\dots)^t(…,0,1,ithλ​,0,…)t.
Of course, if i=1i=1i=1, the image is just λSk−1v\lambda S^{k-1}vλSk−1v, and the column is (λ,0,…,0)T(\lambda,0,\dots,0)^{T}(λ,0,…,0)T.
Either case, this is also the iiith column of the Jordan matrix.

  • Hence in general, T∣FλT|_{F_{\lambda}}T∣Fλ​​ can be made into a JNF of Jordan blocks Jki(λ)J_{k_{i}}(\lambda)Jki​​(λ).

Proof: apply the previous result to the ordered set-basis Bλ=∪ic(vi)B_{\lambda}=\cup_{i}c(v_{i})Bλ​=∪i​c(vi​) of FλF_{\lambda}Fλ​.

Proof: JNF on the Entire Vector Space

Big idea: we decompose the vector space into generalized eigenspaces, where the map has a JNF, and piece them together.

  • Say the minimal polynomial is factorized intomA(x)=(x−λ1)k1…(x−λr)krm_{A}(x)=(x-\lambda _{1})^{k_{1}}\dots(x-\lambda_{r})^{k_{r}}mA​(x)=(x−λ1​)k1​…(x−λr​)kr​where λ1…r\lambda_{1 \dots r}λ1…r​ are distinct eigenvalues.
  • Since we assume linear factorization of the minimal polynomial, the Primary Decomposition Theorem guarantees the block-diagonal form B[T]B=diagi=1∼r(Bλi[T∣Fλi]Bλi)(∗)\begin{align*} _{B}[T]_{B}=\underset{i=1\sim r}{\mathrm{diag}}(_{B \lambda_{i}}[T|_{F \lambda_{i}}]_{B \lambda_{i}}) & &(*) \end{align*}B​[T]B​=i=1∼rdiag​(Bλi​​[T∣Fλi​​]Bλi​​)​​(∗)​for some to-be-determined basis BλiB_{\lambda_{i}}Bλi​​ of Fλi=ker⁡(A−λiI)kiF_{\lambda_{i}}=\ker(A-\lambda_{i} I)^{k_{i}}Fλi​​=ker(A−λi​I)ki​.
  • The previous section gives a basis BλiB_{\lambda_{i}}Bλi​​ composed of Jordan chains, which makes the iiith block a JNF. Now under their union B=∪i=1rBλiB=\cup_{i=1}^{r}B_{\lambda_{i}}B=∪i=1r​Bλi​​, all the diagonal blocks are Jordan blocks, hence the map is made into the JNF B[T]B=(Jk1(λ1)0⋱0Jks(λr))_{B}[T]_{B}=\begin{pmatrix}J_{k_{1}}(\lambda_{1}) & &0 \\ & \ddots \\ 0&&J_{k_{s}}(\lambda_{r}) \end{pmatrix}B​[T]B​=⎝⎛​Jk1​​(λ1​)0​⋱​0Jks​​(λr​)​⎠⎞​and hence the JNF always exists, given a linear factorization of the minimal polynomial.

Solving the Jordan Basis and JNF

  • The Jordan basis of a map is the basis under which the map is represented by its JNF. As seen earlier, it is composed of Jordan chains.
  • The number of Jordan blocks of eigenvalue λ\lambdaλ equals its geometric multiplicity, i.e. the dimension of its ordinary eigenspace.
    • For example, if AAA has characteristic χA(x)=(x−1)4\chi_{A}(x)=(x-1)^4χA​(x)=(x−1)4, and the eigenvalue 111 has geometric multiplicity 222, then there must be two Jordan blocks of diagonal 111 in the JNF, so KaTeX parse error: \hline valid only within array environment

Proof: let JJJ be the JNF, then J−λIJ-\lambda IJ−λI would have one all-000 row for every Jordan block, and the dimension of ker⁡(J−λI)\ker (J-\lambda I)ker(J−λI) is exactly this.

  • In the minimal polynomial, the degree kkk of (x−λ)k(x-\lambda)^k(x−λ)k equals the size of the largest Jordan block with diagonal λ\lambdaλ in the JNF.
    • For example, if the same AAA has a minimal polynomial of mA(x)=(x−1)2m_{A}(x)=(x-1)^2mA​(x)=(x−1)2, then its largest Jordan block is (2×2)(2\times2)(2×2). Hence it can’t have (1×1)+(3×3)(1\times 1)+(3\times 3)(1×1)+(3×3) blocks in the JNF, which must be KaTeX parse error: \hline valid only within array environment
  • Example: solve for the Jordan basis of A=(1−10−14−1−413−3)A=\begin{pmatrix}1 & -1 & 0 \\-1 & 4 & -1 \\-4 & 13 & -3\end{pmatrix}A=⎝⎛​1−1−4​−1413​0−1−3​⎠⎞​.

The characteristic polynomial is χA(x)=−x(x−1)2\chi_{A}(x)=-x(x-1)^2χA​(x)=−x(x−1)2, giving eigenvalues 0,10,10,1. Since basis changes preserve the characteristic, this is also the characteristic of the JNF matrix.

So we will be looking for a JNF with one 000 and two 111's on its diagonal. To find the Jordan basis, we find the Jordan chain for each eigenvalue.

For λ=0\lambda=0λ=0, its block is 1×11\times 11×1, so there is no need for solving the Jordan chain–it only has one element, which is the (regular) eigenvector (1,1,3)T(1,1,3)^{T}(1,1,3)T.

For λ=1\lambda=1λ=1, it could either have one (2×2)(2\times{2})(2×2) block or two (1×1)(1\times{1})(1×1) ones. Since (A−1I)(A-1I)(A−1I) has rank=2\mathrm{rank}=2rank=2, the geometric multiplicity of 111 is dim⁡ker⁡(A−1I)=3−2=1\dim\ker(A-1I)=3-2=1dimker(A−1I)=3−2=1, and there is only one block.

To find the Jordan chain {(A−1I)v, v}\{ (A-1I)v,\, v \}{(A−1I)v,v}, first find ker⁡(A−1I)=⟨(1,0,−1)T⟩\ker(A-1I)=\langle(1,0,-1)^{T}\rangleker(A−1I)=⟨(1,0,−1)T⟩, and the Jordan chain has another element v≠0:(A−I)v∈ker⁡(A−1I)v \ne \mathbf{0}:(A-I)v\in \ker(A-1I)v=0:(A−I)v∈ker(A−1I).
So solve for (A−I)v=(1,0,−1)T(A-I)v=(1,0,-1)^{T}(A−I)v=(1,0,−1)T, giving v=(−3,−1,0)Tv=(-3,-1,0)^{T}v=(−3,−1,0)T, and the Jordan chain is {(1,0,−1)T, (−3,−1,0)T}\{(1,0,-1)^{T},\,(-3,-1,0)^{T} \}{(1,0,−1)T,(−3,−1,0)T}.

Putting the two bases together we get the Jordan basis{(1,1,3)T, (1,0,−1)T, (−3,−1,0)T}\{ (1,1,3)^{T},\,(1,0,-1)^{T},\, (-3,-1,0)^{T}\}{(1,1,3)T,(1,0,−1)T,(−3,−1,0)T}, and the JNF KaTeX parse error: \hline valid only within array environment , where SSS has the Jordan basis as its columns.

  • Example (multiple blocks of the same eigenvalue):
    solve for the Jordan basis of A=(−2−11147−7105−5)A=\begin{pmatrix}-2 & -1 & 1 \\14 & 7 & -7 \\10 & 5 & -5\end{pmatrix}A=⎝⎛​−21410​−175​1−7−5​⎠⎞​.

Solving (A−0I)v=0(A-0I)v=\mathbf{0}(A−0I)v=0 gives eigenvectors (1,−2,0)T(1,-2,0)^{T}(1,−2,0)T and (1,0,2)T(1,0,2)^{T}(1,0,2)T, so ker⁡(A−0I)=⟨(1,−2,0)T,(1,0,2)T⟩\ker(A-0I)=\langle (1,-2,0)^{T},(1,0,2)^{T}\rangleker(A−0I)=⟨(1,−2,0)T,(1,0,2)T⟩.

Dual Spaces

Definitions

  • Given a vector space VVV over F\mathbb FF, its dual (space) is V′=Hom(V,F)V'=\mathrm{Hom}(V,\mathbb F)V′=Hom(V,F), the vector space of linear maps V→FV\to\mathbb FV→F.
  • The elements of a dual are called linear functionals.
    • For example, f→∫01f dxf\to \int_{0}^{1}f \, dxf→∫01​fdx is a linear functional in (C[0,1])′(C[0,1])'(C[0,1])′.
    • Linear functionals have rank 111 and nullity n−1n-1n−1, and the preimage of a constant under a linear functional is an (affine) (n−1)(n-1)(n−1)-dimensional hyperplane.
  • The dual basis B′={ei′}⊂V′\mathcal B'=\{ e'_{i} \}\subset V'B′={ei′​}⊂V′ of a basis B={ei}⊂V\mathcal B=\{ e_{i} \}\subset VB={ei​}⊂V is defined as: ei′:ei′(ej)≡δije'_{i}:e_i'(e_j)\equiv\delta_{ij}ei′​:ei′​(ej​)≡δij​and it forms a basis of V′V'V′.
    • That is, ei′e_i'ei′​ is the projection map onto the eie_iei​ direction.
    • This definition is relative to a basis; the dual basis of a stand-alone vector is undefined, and it can be different in different bases.
  • For finite-dimensional vector spaces, dim⁡V=dim⁡V′\dim V=\dim V'dimV=dimV′.

Proof: the basis BBB of VVV and its dual basis in V′V'V′ have the same size.

  • V′′=(V′)′V'' = (V')'V′′=(V′)′ is the dual of the dual, and the evaluation map Ev∈V′′E_v\in V''Ev​∈V′′ is given by: Ev:V′→F:  Ev(f)=f(v)E_v: V'\to \mathbb{F} :\ \ E_v(f)=f(v)Ev​:V′→F:  Ev​(f)=f(v)
  • When VVV is finite-dimensional, there is a “natural” linear isomorphism v→Evv\to E_vv→Ev​, so V≅V′′V\cong V''V≅V′′.
    • this map is independent of the basis of VVV, unlike the dual basis.
    • it is not an isomorphism if VVV is infinite-dimensional.

Proof (for bijection):
Injection: we will show that v=0  ⟺  Ev=0v=0 \iff E_{v}=0v=0⟺Ev​=0: obviously if v=0v=0v=0, any linear map f∈V′f \in V'f∈V′ must be zero when evaluated by Ev=0E_{v=0}Ev=0​.
Conversely, assume Ev=0E_{v}=0Ev​=0, so ∀f∈V′, f(v)=0\forall f \in V',\, f(v)=0∀f∈V′,f(v)=0. Assume for contradiction that v≠0v \ne 0v=0: we can extend vvv to a basis B\mathcal{B}B of VVV and take the dual basis B′∋v′\mathcal{B}' \ni v'B′∋v′; but Ev(v′)=v′(v)=1E_{v}(v')=v'(v)=1Ev​(v′)=v′(v)=1, a contradiction.

Surjection follows since dim⁡V′′=dim⁡V′=dim⁡V\dim V''=\dim V' = \dim VdimV′′=dimV′=dimV.

Annihilators

  • Given a subspace U≤VU\le VU≤V, its annihilator is U0={f∈V′:f(U)={0}}U^0=\big\{f\in V':f(U)=\{0\}\big\}U0={f∈V′:f(U)={0}}.
  • The annihilator is a subspace of V′V'V′.

Proof: apply the subspace test (closure, contains the zero function).

  • U0≅(V/U)′U^0 \cong (V/U)'U0≅(V/U)′, hence for finite-dimensional vector spaces,
    dim⁡U0=dim⁡V−dim⁡U\dim U^0=\dim V-\dim UdimU0=dimV−dimU

Proof: ϕ:f↦f′, f′(v+U)≡f(v)\phi:f\mapsto f',\,f'(v+U) \equiv f(v)ϕ:f↦f′,f′(v+U)≡f(v) is an linear injection. It is a bijection since it has inverse ϕ−1(g)=g∗, g∗(v)=g(v+U)\phi^{-1}(g)=g^{*},\,g^*(v)=g(v+U)ϕ−1(g)=g∗,g∗(v)=g(v+U), which can be shown to be linear and maps into U0U^0U0.

The dimension equality then follows for finite vector spaces.

  • If VVV is finite-dimensional, the natural isomorphism V→V′′V\to V''V→V′′ given by v→Evv\to E_vv→Ev​ is also an isomorphism U≅U00U\cong U^{00}U≅U00, where U≤VU\le VU≤V.

Proof: UUU is linearly mapped into U00U^{00}U00, as {Eu:u∈U}\{ E_u: u\in U \}{Eu​:u∈U} annihilates U0U^0U0.
Applying the previous result twice shows that the image has the same dimension as U00U^{00}U00, hence the two are the same, and the map is a bijection.

Dual Maps

  • A linear map T:V→WT:V\to WT:V→W has a dual map T′:W′→V′T':W'\to V'T′:W′→V′ given by pre-composition with TTT: T′(f)≡f∘TT'(f)\equiv f\circ TT′(f)≡f∘T  VundefinedT′(f)FT↓WundefinedTf′()F\begin{align*} &\ V\xrightarrow {T'(f)}\mathbb{F}\\T &\downarrow \\ &W\xrightarrow{\hphantom{T}f\hphantom{'()}}\mathbb F\end{align*}T​ VT′(f)​F↓WTf′()​F​(this is supposed to be a triangle, but IDK how to draw one).
  • Assigning T→T′T\to T'T→T′ gives an isomorphism Hom(V,W)≅Hom(W′,V′)\mathrm{Hom}(V,W) \cong \mathrm{Hom}(W',V')Hom(V,W)≅Hom(W′,V′) when V,WV,WV,W are finite dimensional.

Proof: check for linearity.
For injectivity, we prove that T′=0T'=0T′=0 requires T=0T=0T=0: T′=0Hom(W′,V′)  ⟺  ∀f∈W′:T′(f)=0V′  ⟺  ∀f∈W′,v∈V:f(Tv)=0  ⟺  ∀v∈V: ETv=0W′′  ⟺  ∀v∈V:Tv=0W  ⟺  T=0Hom(V,W)\begin{align*} T'=0_{\mathrm{Hom}(W',V')} &\iff \forall f\in W':T'(f)=0_{ V'}\\ &\iff \forall f\in W',v\in V: f(Tv)=0\\ &\iff \forall v \in V:\,E_{Tv}=0_{W''}\\ &\iff \forall v\in V: Tv=0_{W}\\ &\iff T=0_{\mathrm{Hom}(V,W)} \end{align*}T′=0Hom(W′,V′)​​⟺∀f∈W′:T′(f)=0V′​⟺∀f∈W′,v∈V:f(Tv)=0⟺∀v∈V:ETv​=0W′′​⟺∀v∈V:Tv=0W​⟺T=0Hom(V,W)​​And in finite-dimensional spaces, it’s bijective since dim⁡Hom(V,W)=dim⁡Hom(W′,V′)\dim \mathrm{Hom}(V,W)=\dim \mathrm{Hom}(W',V')dimHom(V,W)=dimHom(W′,V′).

  • With linear map T:V→WT: V \to WT:V→W, finite bases BV,BW,\mathcal B_V,\mathcal B_W,BV​,BW​, and their dual bases, there is: BW[T]BVt= BV′[T′]BW′_{\mathcal B_W}[T]_{\mathcal B_V}^t = \ _{\mathcal B_V'}[T']_{\mathcal B_W'}BW​​[T]BV​t​= BV′​​[T′]BW′​​

Proof: write LHSt=(aij),RHS=(bij)\mathrm{LHS}^t=(a_{ij}),\mathrm{RHS}=(b_{ij})LHSt=(aij​),RHS=(bij​), then check aija_{ij}aij​ and bjib_{ji}bji​ are the same by writing them in terms of dual bases, TTT, and T′T'T′.

Inner Product Spaces

Definitions

  • A real vector space VVV equipped with a positive-definite, symmetric bilinear form <∗,∗>\left< *,* \right>⟨∗,∗⟩ is called a (real) inner product space.
    • Positive-definiteness: <v,v>≥0\left< v,v \right> \ge 0⟨v,v⟩≥0, equality only when v=0v=\mathbf{0}v=0.
    • Symmetry: <v,w>=<w,v>\left< v,w \right> = \left< w,v \right>⟨v,w⟩=⟨w,v⟩
    • Bilinearity: <u+v,w>=<u,w>+<v,w>\left< u+v,w \right> = \left< u,w \right> + \left< v,w \right>⟨u+v,w⟩=⟨u,w⟩+⟨v,w⟩, <λu,v>=λ<u,v>\left< \lambda u,v \right> = \lambda\left< u,v \right>⟨λu,v⟩=λ⟨u,v⟩.

  • A complex vector space equipped with a positive-definite, conjugate-symmetric sesquilinear form is called a (complex) inner product space.

    • Conjugate-symmetry: ⟨v,w⟩=⟨w,v⟩‾\langle v,w\rangle=\overline{\langle w,v \rangle}⟨v,w⟩=⟨w,v⟩​
    • Sesquilinearity: ⟨λˉv,w⟩=λ⟨v,w⟩=⟨v,λw⟩\langle \bar{\lambda} v,w\rangle=\lambda\langle v,w\rangle=\langle v,\lambda w \rangle⟨λˉv,w⟩=λ⟨v,w⟩=⟨v,λw⟩.

  • Vectors {vi}\{ v_{i} \}{vi​} are orthogonal if <vi,vj≠i>=0\left< v_{i},v_{j \ne i} \right> = 0⟨vi​,vj=i​⟩=0, and they are orthonormal if <vi,vj>=δij\left< v_{i},v_{j} \right> = \delta_{ij}⟨vi​,vj​⟩=δij​.

  • Orthogonal (and non-000) vectors are linearly independent (in either real and complex IPS).

Proof: if a linear combination of those vectors is 000, then taking the inner product with each of them shows that the coefficients are all 000.

Gram-Schmidt in IPS

Big idea: Gram-Schmidt generates an othonormal basis by removing all the non-orthogonal components a basis vector has in the direction of others.

  • The projection of vvv onto www is the component vvv has in the direction of www, if they are ordinary vectors in Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn; in general, pw(v)=(⟨w,v⟩⟨w,w⟩undefinedprojection length)(w⟨w,w⟩undefinedalong w)=⟨w,v⟩⟨w,w⟩wp_{w}(v)=\bigg(\underbrace{ \frac{\langle w,v \rangle}{\sqrt{ \langle w,w \rangle }} }_{\text{projection length}}\bigg)\bigg(\underbrace{ \frac{w}{\sqrt{ \langle w,w \rangle }}}_{\text{along } w}\bigg )=\frac{\langle w,v \rangle}{\langle w,w \rangle}wpw​(v)=(projection length⟨w,w⟩​⟨w,v⟩​​​)(along w⟨w,w⟩​w​​​)=⟨w,w⟩⟨w,v⟩​w
  • Then v−pw(v)v-p_{w}(v)v−pw​(v) is orthogonal to www. Intuitively, what remains from −pw(v)-p_{w}(v)−pw​(v) should indeed be “unrelated” to www.
  • The Gram-Schmidt Process: given independent vectors v1,…,vnv_{1},\dots,v_{n}v1​,…,vn​ in an inner product space VVV, we can construct an orthogonal basis w1,…,wnw_{1}, \dots, w_{n}w1​,…,wn​ given by the recursive formula wi=vi−∑k=1i−1pwk(vi)w_{i}=v_{i}-\sum_{k=1}^{i-1}p_{w_{k}}(v_{i})wi​=vi​−k=1∑i−1​pwk​​(vi​)that is, we add viv_{i}vi​ to the new basis after making it orthogonal to each of w1,…,wi−1w_{1}, \dots, w_{i-1}w1​,…,wi−1​.
    • If we wish, taking wi∗=wi/⟨wi,wi⟩w_{i}^{*}=w_{i} / \sqrt{ \langle w_{i}, w_{i}\rangle }wi∗​=wi​/⟨wi​,wi​⟩​ gives an orthonormal basis.
    • Hence every real or complex IPS has an othonormal basis.

Duals and Orthogonal Complements

  • The map v→⟨v,∗⟩v\to \langle v,*\ranglev→⟨v,∗⟩ is an injective linear map V→V′V\to V'V→V′, hence an isomorphism V≅V′V \cong V'V≅V′ when VVV is finite in dimension.

Proof: linearity is easily confirmed.
Injectivity can be derived from non-degeneracy: ⟨v,∗⟩\langle v,* \rangle⟨v,∗⟩ is not the zero function (in particular, ⟨v,v⟩≠0\langle v,v \rangle \ne 0⟨v,v⟩=0) unless v=0v=0v=0 due to positive-definiteness.

  • The orthogonal complement U⊥U^{\perp}U⊥ of a subspace U≤VU\le VU≤V, VVV an IPS is U⊥={v∈V:⟨U,v⟩={0}}U^{\perp}=\{ v\in V: \langle U, v \rangle=\{ 0 \}\}U⊥={v∈V:⟨U,v⟩={0}}
    • The orthogonal complement is a subspace.
  • A subspace and its orthogonal complement form a direct sum in finite-dimensional vector spaces.

Proof: take U≤VU\le VU≤V, orthonormal basis BUB_{U}BU​ and extend it to an orthonormal basis BVB_{V}BV​ of VVV. We will prove that BC=BV∖BUB_{C}=B_{V}\setminus B_{U}BC​=BV​∖BU​ is a basis of U⊥U^\perpU⊥, which completes the proof.

Spanning: for any vector v∈U⊥v \in U^\perpv∈U⊥, decompose it in terms of BVB_{V}BV​. Inner product ⟨v,ui⟩\langle v,u_{i} \rangle⟨v,ui​⟩ with ui∈BUu_{i}\in B_{U}ui​∈BU​ shows that their coefficients are 000, so U⊥⊆⟨Bc⟩U^{\perp}\subseteq\langle B_{c} \rangleU⊥⊆⟨Bc​⟩.
Independence: immediate from BcB_{c}Bc​ being a subset of a basis.
Containment: due to orthonormality, Bc⊂U⊥B_{c} \subset U^{\perp}Bc​⊂U⊥.

  • If VVV is a finite dimensional IPS with U≤VU\le VU≤V, U⊥≅U0U^{\perp}\cong U^0U⊥≅U0.

Proof: consider the map w→⟨w,∗⟩w\to \langle w, *\ranglew→⟨w,∗⟩ for w∈U⊥w \in U^{\perp}w∈U⊥.
It maps into U0U^0U0 by definition of orthogonal complements.
Its injectiveness and linearity is proven above in V≅V′:v→⟨v,∗⟩V \cong V':v \to \langle v,\ast \rangleV≅V′:v→⟨v,∗⟩.
Since dim⁡U⊥=dim⁡U0\dim U^{\perp}=\dim U^{0}dimU⊥=dimU0 in finite-dimensional VVV, it is bijective.

Adjoints

  • Given map T:V→VT: V\to VT:V→V, VVV a real/complex IPS, the adjoint of TTT is a map T∗T^*T∗ such that ∀v,w∈V:⟨v,Tw⟩=⟨T∗v,w⟩\forall v,w\in V:\langle v, Tw \rangle= \langle T^{*}v,w \rangle∀v,w∈V:⟨v,Tw⟩=⟨T∗v,w⟩
    • Adjoints of a map, if any exist, are unique.

Proof: if T∗,T+T^{*},T^{+}T∗,T+ are both adjoints, then ∀v,w∈V,  <(T∗v−T+v,w>=0\forall v,w \in V,\, \,\left< (T^{*}v-T^{+}v,w \right> = 0 ∀v,w∈V,⟨(T∗v−T+v,w⟩=0then choose w=T∗v−T+vw=T^{*}v-T^{+}vw=T∗v−T+v, and non-degeneracy of the inner product requires T∗v−T+v=0T^{*}v-T^{+}v=\mathbf{0}T∗v−T+v=0 for any vvv.

  • In a finite-dimensional IPS, the adjoint always exists and is linear.

Proof: for each vvv, we find a suitable u=T∗vu=T^{*}vu=T∗v to satisfy the definiton.
The map v↦⟨v,T(∗)⟩v \mapsto \langle v,T(*)\ranglev↦⟨v,T(∗)⟩ is a linear map V→V′V\to V'V→V′, and since VVV is finite dimensional, the isomorphism V≅V′V\cong V'V≅V′ guarantees ∃!u:⟨u,∗⟩=⟨v,T(∗)⟩\exists! u:\langle u,*\rangle=\langle v, T(*)\rangle∃!u:⟨u,∗⟩=⟨v,T(∗)⟩.
Define T∗v≡uT^{*}v\equiv uT∗v≡u, then verify linearity.

  • Under an orthonormal basis B\mathcal{B}B of VVV, the matrices of a map and its adjoint are conjugate transposes of each other.
    • That is, adjoint of a map is equivalent to the transpose of a matrix.
      B[T∗]B=(B[T]B‾)t_{\mathcal{B}}[T^{*}]_{\mathcal{B}}=(\overline{_{\mathcal{B}}[T]_{\mathcal{B}}})^tB​[T∗]B​=(B​[T]B​​)t

Proof: let B={e1,…,en}, LHS=(aij), RHS‾t=B[T]B=(bij)\mathcal{B}=\{ e_{1},\dots, e_{n} \},\,\mathrm{LHS}=(a_{ij}),\, \overline{\mathrm{RHS}}^{t}= \hphantom{}_{\mathcal{B}}[T]_{\mathcal{B}}=(b_{ij})B={e1​,…,en​},LHS=(aij​),RHSt=B​[T]B​=(bij​).
Then aij=⟨ei, T∗ej⟩=⟨T∗ej,ei⟩‾=⟨ej,Tei⟩‾=bji‾a_{ij}=\langle e_{i},\, T^{*}e_{j}\rangle=\overline{\langle T^{*}e_{j}, e_{i} \rangle}=\overline{\langle e_{j}, Te_{i} \rangle}=\overline{ b_{ji}}aij​=⟨ei​,T∗ej​⟩=⟨T∗ej​,ei​⟩​=⟨ej​,Tei​⟩​=bji​​.

  • A map is self-adjoint if it is its own adjoint.
    • Self adjoints are the IPS equivalent for symmetric matrices.
  • Self-adjoint maps have and only have real eigenvalues.

Proof: linear map TTT always has eigenvalue λ∈C\lambda \in \mathbb{C}λ∈C.
Take w≠0:Tw=λww \ne \mathbf{0}:Tw=\lambda ww=0:Tw=λw, then λ⟨w,w⟩=<w,λw>=<w,Tw>=<T∗w,w>=<Tw,w>=<λw,w>=λˉ⟨w,w⟩\begin{align*} \lambda\langle w,w \rangle&= \left< w,\lambda w \right> \\ &= \left< w,Tw \right> \\ &= \left< T^{*}w,w \right>\\ &= \left< Tw,w \right> \\ &= \left< \lambda w,w \right> \\ &= \bar{\lambda} \langle w,w \rangle \end{align*}λ⟨w,w⟩​=⟨w,λw⟩=⟨w,Tw⟩=⟨T∗w,w⟩=⟨Tw,w⟩=⟨λw,w⟩=λˉ⟨w,w⟩​so λ∈R\lambda \in \mathbb{R}λ∈R.

  • If UUU is invariant under a self-adjoint map TTT, so is U⊥U^\perpU⊥.

Proof: if u∈U,w∈U⊥u \in U,w\in U^\perpu∈U,w∈U⊥, then Tw∈U⊥Tw\in U^\perpTw∈U⊥ because ⟨u,Tw⟩=⟨T∗u,w⟩=⟨Tu,w⟩=0\langle u,Tw \rangle=\langle T^{*}u, w \rangle=\langle Tu, w \rangle=0⟨u,Tw⟩=⟨T∗u,w⟩=⟨Tu,w⟩=0.

  • Spectral Theorem (for self-adjoint maps): self-adjoint maps in finite dimensional vector spaces over R\mathbb{R}R can be diagonalized. That is, there exists a real orthonormal basis made of its eigenvectors.

Proof: say TTT self-adjoint in IPS VVV with dimension nnn.
Take any eigenvalue/vector pair λ,v:Tv=λv\lambda,v:Tv=\lambda vλ,v:Tv=λv. The span ⟨v⟩\langle v \rangle⟨v⟩ is TTT-invariant, so is ⟨v⟩⊥\langle v \rangle^\perp⟨v⟩⊥. Now TTT is still self-adjoint when restricted to ⟨v⟩⊥\langle v \rangle^\perp⟨v⟩⊥, so we add vvv to the basis and work with ⟨v⟩⊥\langle v \rangle^\perp⟨v⟩⊥, an IPS with dimension (n−1)(n-1)(n−1).
Induction on nnn, the dimension of the IPS, gives an orthgonal basis made up of the eigenvectors of TTT. Normalizing each vector gives an orthonormal basis.

Orthogonal and Unitary Maps

  • In an IPS VVV with an orthonormal basis {e1,…,en}\{ e_{1},\dots, e_{n} \}{e1​,…,en​}, if a matrix AAA has these basis vectors in its columns, it satisfies AAtˉ=AtˉA=IA \bar{A^t}=\bar{A^t}A=IAAtˉ=AtˉA=Iand matrices satisfying this equation are called orthogonal in a real IPS, or unitary in a complex IPS.

  • A linear map TTT is called orthogonal/unitary if T∗=T−1T^{*}=T^{-1}T∗=T−1.

  • TTT is orthogonal/unitary   ⟺  \iff⟺ TTT preserves inner products.

    • this implies that all the eigenvalues of TTT have modulus 111

  • The length function determines the inner product: knowing ⟨v,v⟩1=⟨v,v⟩2\langle v,v \rangle_{1}=\langle v,v \rangle_{2}⟨v,v⟩1​=⟨v,v⟩2​ determines ⟨v,w⟩2=⟨v,w⟩2\langle v,w \rangle_{2}=\langle v,w \rangle_{2}⟨v,w⟩2​=⟨v,w⟩2​ for any v,w∈Vv,w \in Vv,w∈V.

Proof: expand ⟨v+w,v+w⟩\langle v+w,v+w \rangle⟨v+w,v+w⟩, so that ⟨v,w⟩\langle v,w \rangle⟨v,w⟩ can be expressed in terms of lengths. Hence determining the length function also determines the inner product.

For complex vector fields, the above only determines the real part; to show the same for the imaginary part, consider ⟨v+iw,v+iw⟩\langle v+iw, v+iw \rangle⟨v+iw,v+iw⟩.

  • If TTT is orthogonal/unitary, then if UUU is TTT-invariant, so is U⊥U^\perpU⊥.

Proof: same strategy as in the proof for self-adjoint maps.
Note that T−1T^{-1}T−1 is a polynomial of TTT: let mT=a0+xm∗(x)m_{T}=a_{0}+xm^{*}(x)mT​=a0​+xm∗(x), then Tm∗(T)=−a0ITm^{*}(T)=-a_{0}ITm∗(T)=−a0​I, and T−1=−m∗(T)/a0T^{-1}=-m^{*}(T) / a_{0}T−1=−m∗(T)/a0​. Hence UUU is also invariant under T−1T^{-1}T−1.

  • Spectral Theorem (for unitary maps): unitary maps in finite dimensional complex vector spaces can be diagonalized. That is, there exists an orthonormal basis made of its eigenvectors.
    • Note that if TTT is an orthogonal map in a real vector space, it might not be diagonalizable even though it is a unitary map in the corresponding complex vector space.

Proof: again, follow the same strategy as in the proof for self-adjoints.

  • Instead of a full diagonalization, orthogonal maps in finite dimensional real vector spaces can be made into a block diagonal, with each block either be ±I\pm I±I or a rotation-by-θ\thetaθ matrix.

Proof: see the lecture notes. I’m feeling lazy.
